nodes.text: Investigate how government debt (internal and external) affects long-run competitive equilibrium, individual utility, and capital accumulation in a neoclassical growth model with overlapping generations

Method: Construct a discrete-time overlapping-generations model with infinitely lived economy, two-period lived individuals, aggregate production F(K,L) with constant returns to scale, no depreciation, and identical lifetime utility U(e1,e2)

Assumptions on public debt and taxation: all government debt has one-period maturity, debt-labor ratio is held constant (debt grows at population growth rate n), interest paid at current rate, and financing taxes are lump-sum on the young

Context/benchmark: Central planner can choose Golden Age paths with constant capital-labor ratio; Golden Rule capital-labor ratio maximizes per-capita consumption where marginal product of capital equals population growth rate (fK = n)
Claim: Competitive market solution may be dynamically inefficient (capital-labor ratio can exceed Golden Rule) despite absence of usual inefficiencies

Method: Derive individual optimization and aggregate supply of capital: individuals choose consumption across two periods given wage wt and one-period interest rt+1, producing saving function s(wt, rt+1) and aggregate supply S = Lt s(wt, rt+1)

Method/Claim: Capital market equilibrium equates aggregate saving per worker to next-period capital per worker: rt+1 = f'( s(wt, rt+1)/(1+n) ), producing an i function relating rt+1 to wt and a factor-price frontier w = w(r)

Result: Relative slopes of saving (supply) and demand (marginal product) curves produce two cases; in the 'normal' case higher current wage raises long-run saving and lowers equilibrium interest, while alternative case (discussed separately) can reverse effects
Method: Analyze long-run equilibria graphically by composing the i function and the factor-price frontier to obtain a unique stable equilibrium (stability condition derived)

Claim: External debt affects the domestic long-run equilibrium only via taxes needed to finance interest payments (no direct domestic purchase of capital), shifting the i function and changing equilibrium r and w

Result/Evidence: In the 'normal' (efficient) case where r > n, introducing external debt increases taxes, reduces disposable income and savings, lowers capital stock, raises equilibrium interest rate away from Golden Rule, and reduces individual lifetime utility

Claim: Internal debt changes both supply (via taxes) and demand (government holds domestic debt on demand side), substituting government debt for physical capital in private portfolios and directly reducing capital stock and output

Result/Evidence: Internal debt, by adding government demand for loanable funds and substituting paper for capital, raises equilibrium interest rate, reduces capital-labor ratio, and in the efficient case (r > n) lowers individual utility (pure domestic effect analogous to external debt's third term)

Claim/Result: The sign of the welfare effect of either type of debt depends on whether equilibrium interest rate r exceeds, equals, or is less than population growth n: when r > n (efficient), debt issuance lowers utility; when r < n (dynamically inefficient) debt may raise utility

Result: Swapping external debt for internal debt (retire external by issuing internal) raises equilibrium interest rate (demand-side effect), increases taxes or interest burden, and in the efficient case unambiguously lowers utility; in inefficient case sign ambiguous depending on parameter magnitudes

Limitation/Methodological scope: Analysis focuses on long-run differential incidence (substituting debt for taxes) and abstracts from short-run incidence, welfare social aggregation rules, bequests, and other possible tax schemes; some special cases relegated to appendices
